rev.comment: /* Lawsuit by Authors Guild */ hilight Fair Use and the four factors, and minor editing
rev.diff:
Line 184: Line 184:
====Lawsuit by Authors Guild====
====Lawsuit by Authors Guild====
â
On [[September 20]], 2005, the Authors Guild, a group that represents 8000 US authors,
+
On [[September 20]], 2005, the Authors Guild, a group that represents 8000 US authors, with a children's book author, and a former Poet Laureate of the United States, filed a class action suit in federal court in Manhattan against Google over its unauthorized scanning and copying of books through its Google Library program. The lawsuit seeks damages and an injunction that will prevent the company from continuing their very ambitious digitization project. Arguments in the case will hinge around the interpretation of [[Fair use#Fair use under United States law|the four factors of Fair Use]].
â
with a children's book author, and a former Poet Laureate of the United States, filed a class action suit in federal court in Manhattan against Google over its unauthorized scanning and copying of books through its Google Library program. The lawsuit seeks damages and an injunction that will prevent the company from
  â
continuing their very ambitious digitization project
  â
Many commentators in the world of copyright
+
Many commentators in the world of copyright law and technology were not surprised by this development as The Authors Guild has also been involved in attempting to make online publishers pay royalties to writers whose stories appear in any number of online databases without their express consent. In a concession to general concerns about the nature of their project, Google had announced plans back in August that they would respect the wishes of copyright holders who contacted the company to inform them that they did not want their works included in this digitization project.
